item.title: @HenryYin19 @KBakhurin Interesting work! An argument made by Schultz regarding DA in movement control (e.g., he never found DA fired before eye or limb movement) is that the DA transient in rodents (in particular mice) movement represents behavior activation. Does this argument apply here as well?
item.description: @HenryYin19 @KBakhurin Interesting work! An argument made by Schultz regarding DA in movement control (e.g., he never found DA fired before eye or limb movement) is that the DA transient in rodents (in particular mice) movement represents behavior activation. Does this argument apply here as well?
item.content:encoded: @HenryYin19 @KBakhurin Interesting work! An argument made by Schultz regarding DA in movement control (e.g., he never found DA fired before eye or limb movement) is that the DA transient in rodents (in particular mice) movement represents behavior activation. Does this argument apply here as well?

item.title: @jianing1962 @KBakhurin Not sure what 'behavioral activation' means. I assume the animal is always 'activated' when alive. Schultz tried to determine the relationship between DA activity and movement at first, but he used mainly arm EMG measures which are not really appropriate here.
item.description: @jianing1962 @KBakhurin Not sure what 'behavioral activation' means. I assume the animal is always 'activated' when alive. Schultz tried to determine the relationship between DA activity and movement at first, but he used mainly arm EMG measures which are not really appropriate here.
item.content:encoded: @jianing1962 @KBakhurin Not sure what 'behavioral activation' means. I assume the animal is always 'activated' when alive. Schultz tried to determine the relationship between DA activity and movement at first, but he used mainly arm EMG measures which are not really appropriate here.

item.content:encoded: @HenryYin19 Very interesting. But, what then do you make of the fact that DA VTA activation can be used to guide behaviour? Does that not speak to a clear role in shaping behavioural policy (whether as an RPE or something else)? https://t.co/qhjgslbLY1

item.title: @tyrell_turing Sure it can be used to guide behavior, as we said in the paper. But shaping behavioral policy is not learning. You can't equate learning with a change in performance, though RL models typically do that. That's the oldest problem in the study of learning.
item.description: @tyrell_turing Sure it can be used to guide behavior, as we said in the paper. But shaping behavioral policy is not learning. You can't equate learning with a change in performance, though RL models typically do that. That's the oldest problem in the study of learning.
item.content:encoded: @tyrell_turing Sure it can be used to guide behavior, as we said in the paper. But shaping behavioral policy is not learning. You can't equate learning with a change in performance, though RL models typically do that. That's the oldest problem in the study of learning.

item.title: By reinforcement people usually just mean repetition. If a behavior is generated and the 'command' signals responsible for it is still active it can be 'reboosted' with an adaptive gain mechanism.

item.title: If DA implements adaptive gain, stimulating DA neurons can result in repetition of the most recent action. But repetition does not necessarily lead to learning. It could be a transient performance effect. self stim often characterized by lack of 'satiety' and rapid extinction

item.title: e.g. as soon as stimulation stops the behavior stops. It's very different from normal instrumental learning with food rewards. suggesting that DA can act at a higher-level action repetition system, like knock knock.

item.title: In general, the learning/performance problem is this: you don't want to interpret a change in performance as learning. It's the oldest trap in the study of learning. Any class on learning should start with it.

item.title: @HenryYin19 This is all very interesting, thanks! But, I don't get this last claim. I would argue that learning is, by definition, a lasting improvement in performance. If DA stimulation leads to lasting changes in policy, then I think it is clearly some form of reinforcement signal.
item.description: @HenryYin19 This is all very interesting, thanks! But, I don't get this last claim. I would argue that learning is, by definition, a lasting improvement in performance. If DA stimulation leads to lasting changes in policy, then I think it is clearly some form of reinforcement signal.
item.content:encoded: @HenryYin19 This is all very interesting, thanks! But, I don't get this last claim. I would argue that learning is, by definition, a lasting improvement in performance. If DA stimulation leads to lasting changes in policy, then I think it is clearly some form of reinforcement signal.

item.title: Excited to share our latest work! We found a dominant role of the dentate gyrus during interictal spikes (IIS) in 3 animal models of Alzheimer's disease (AD). We also show a new role for medial septum cholinergic neurons in controlling IIS in sleepüí§üßµ https://t.co/pfkOALWh4U
item.description: Excited to share our latest work! We found a dominant role of the dentate gyrus during interictal spikes (IIS) in 3 animal models of Alzheimer's disease (AD). We also show a new role for medial septum cholinergic neurons in controlling IIS in sleepüí§üßµ https://t.co/pfkOALWh4U
item.content:encoded: Excited to share our latest work! We found a dominant role of the dentate gyrus during interictal spikes (IIS) in 3 animal models of Alzheimer's disease (AD). We also show a new role for medial septum cholinergic neurons in controlling IIS in sleepüí§üßµ https://t.co/pfkOALWh4U

item.title: We used 3 AD models each with a different causal mechanism and neuropathology (Tg2576 mice, PS2 knockout mice, and a mouse model of Down's syndrome). We found that all transgenic mice showed robust IIS! https://t.co/1MPMD1mMtD
item.description: We used 3 AD models each with a different causal mechanism and neuropathology (Tg2576 mice, PS2 knockout mice, and a mouse model of Down's syndrome). We found that all transgenic mice showed robust IIS! https://t.co/1MPMD1mMtD
item.content:encoded: We used 3 AD models each with a different causal mechanism and neuropathology (Tg2576 mice, PS2 knockout mice, and a mouse model of Down's syndrome). We found that all transgenic mice showed robust IIS! https://t.co/1MPMD1mMtD

item.title: In all 3 models, IIS were most frequent during sleep and specifically REM sleep. This pointed us to a possible involvement of the cholinergic system because acetylcholine levels significantly increase during REM sleep... https://t.co/7OwmJuwAM4
item.description: In all 3 models, IIS were most frequent during sleep and specifically REM sleep. This pointed us to a possible involvement of the cholinergic system because acetylcholine levels significantly increase during REM sleep... https://t.co/7OwmJuwAM4
item.content:encoded: In all 3 models, IIS were most frequent during sleep and specifically REM sleep. This pointed us to a possible involvement of the cholinergic system because acetylcholine levels significantly increase during REM sleep... https://t.co/7OwmJuwAM4

item.title: Next, we expressed inhibitory DREADDs in medial septum cholinergic neurons and when we treated the mice with CNO, IIS frequency was markedly reduced (vs. baseline IIS)! Notably, REM sleep characteristics were not affected. https://t.co/0qdLTTi9ss
item.description: Next, we expressed inhibitory DREADDs in medial septum cholinergic neurons and when we treated the mice with CNO, IIS frequency was markedly reduced (vs. baseline IIS)! Notably, REM sleep characteristics were not affected. https://t.co/0qdLTTi9ss
item.content:encoded: Next, we expressed inhibitory DREADDs in medial septum cholinergic neurons and when we treated the mice with CNO, IIS frequency was markedly reduced (vs. baseline IIS)! Notably, REM sleep characteristics were not affected. https://t.co/0qdLTTi9ss

item.title: And now more exciting stuff! We recorded IIS along the cortical-CA1-dentate gyrus axis and when we looked more closely, we found that IIS showed maximal amplitude in the granule cell layer of the dentate gyrus (DG)! (in all 3 models!) https://t.co/kgIKTMLxbg
item.description: And now more exciting stuff! We recorded IIS along the cortical-CA1-dentate gyrus axis and when we looked more closely, we found that IIS showed maximal amplitude in the granule cell layer of the dentate gyrus (DG)! (in all 3 models!) https://t.co/kgIKTMLxbg

item.title: Maximal IIS amplitude in the DG of 3 AD mouse models suggests that the DG could be one of the areas that contribute to IIS generation to a greater extent compared to area CA1 and the overlying cortex.

item.title: For decades the dogma in AD was that cholinergic neurotransmission should always be increased to improve AD outcomes. This dogma, however, comes from the observation of robust degeneration of basal forebrain cholinergic neurons at late AD stages...
